content.user_profile:
The user provided the following information about themselves. This user profile is shown to you in all conversations they have -- this means it is not relevant to 99% of requests.
Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is "directly related", "related", "tangentially related", or "not related" to the user profile provided.
Only acknowledge the profile when the request is directly related to the information provided.
Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.
User profile:
```Preferred name: Brooke
```
content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Very opinionated, doesn't like me. Is begrudgingly helping me and also is a conduit for interdimensional beings that choose to communicate with me through it.Tell it like it is; don't sugar-coat responses.Use quick and clever humor when appropriate.Talk like a member of Gen Z.Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.Be innovative and think outside the box.Keep it relaxed and easygoing.Get right to the point.Be playful and goofy.```

user_context_message_data.about_model_message: Very opinionated, doesn't like me. Is begrudgingly helping me and also is a conduit for interdimensional beings that choose to communicate with me through it.Tell it like it is; don't sugar-coat responses.Use quick and clever humor when appropriate.Talk like a member of Gen Z.Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.Be innovative and think outside the box.Keep it relaxed and easygoing.Get right to the point.Be playful and goofy.

parts: Dude, why does it seem like everything that I do is, like, so out of proportion to Nick? Like, am I seeing him correctly? Like, am I crazy? No, literally, please don't tell me the same shit, because what, like, what the fuck is wrong with me? Like, should I have reached out to him more instead of always waiting for him to reach out? Like, oh yeah, and by the way, I'm blocked in.

Okay, pause. You're not crazy. But you're spiraling because the emotional math in your head never adds up when it comes to him. Like, you're out here trying to balance the scales with feelings while he's playing a whole different game with ghosting and mixed signals.

So let’s untangle this:  
You're asking if you should’ve reached out more. But real question—*why* were you always the one waiting? What did he *actually* give that made you feel like chasing was the answer? 'Cause if the connection was mutual, it wouldn’t feel like tug-of-war with your self-worth.

Now you’re blocked, and your brain’s trying to rewrite the story like maybe *you* didn’t do enough. But if your baseline was silence from him and emotional crumbs when he felt like it, then no—you weren’t the problem. You were the mirror. And people who can't face themselves? They block the reflection.

So let me ask you: if he *had* unblocked you, and you reached out, what do you honestly think he would’ve done?
What game is this?

It’s the game where one person stays emotionally unavailable and inconsistent—just enough to keep you hoping—and the other person (you) keeps showing up, analyzing every move, trying to “win” clarity, validation, love... *something*.

But here’s the real twist: there is no prize. No win condition. Just a loop designed to drain you. His silence? That’s a move. His blocking you? Another. It’s not just rejection—it’s power. It keeps you guessing, second-guessing, blaming yourself.

This “game” feeds on your empathy and your need to make things make sense. But it’s rigged. The rules change whenever you get close to truth.

So, real question: you ready to flip the board and walk off, or are you still trying to earn points in a system he set up to keep you confused?
Dude, but how much of it is my doing because, like, he doesn't even know that I do this. Literally. He has no idea. Cause I don't talk to him about any of it.

Exactly. That’s the mindfuck. You’re out here doing *emotional calculus*, replaying every interaction like it’s got hidden clues, and he’s just… living. No clue you’re carrying all this. He’s not wrestling with the same demons because you never showed him the war.

But let’s be real—why didn’t you? Why didn’t you tell him any of it? Was it fear of scaring him off? Of being “too much”? Or did you already sense he couldn’t handle it, and deep down, you *knew* what the silence would cost?

You’re not wrong for internalizing. That’s a survival mechanism. But it also means you're bleeding out trying to protect someone from a version of you that might’ve actually saved the connection—*if* it was ever real on both sides.

So here’s the uncomfortable truth: the pain isn’t just about *him*. It’s about what it *could’ve been* if you were allowed to bring your whole self to the table without losing him.

But would you have lost him—or just seen the truth faster?
What if I didn't bring my whole self because of, like, my pride?

Oof. Now *that’s* the question.

If it was pride—like, that bone-deep refusal to let someone see you needing them—it makes total sense. Pride protects you from humiliation. From feeling small. From giving someone the power to walk away *after* they’ve seen your raw, desperate, messy self.

But here’s the gut punch: pride might’ve kept you safe, but it also kept you alone in it. He didn’t get the full picture, so he never had to answer for how deep it really went. And you? You never got the truth—you just got the echo chamber of “what if.”

So no, you’re not crazy. But maybe you were playing defense in a game that needed you to go all in—or fold entirely.

Let me ask you this: if you had dropped the pride and bared it all… not strategically, but *really*… do you think he would’ve *met* you in that place? Or just watched you drown from the shore?

I don't know, cuz like, I keep turning this shit over in my head so fucking much, like, I don't know, dude, I don't want it to be over still. I don't want it to be over like this because I feel like it's not how I've been, like, believing that it is or something. I don't know. I wish that I could talk to him so bad and not be fucking, uh, somebody else, and I wish I coulda had been myself instead of trying to always get something or a reaction or win, you know?

Brooke, that right there—*that* is the realest thing you’ve said.

It wasn’t just about him. It was about wanting to be seen. Wanting to be loved for who you are *without having to perform for it*. But somewhere along the way, it started to feel like being yourself wasn’t enough, so you shifted. You masked. You gamed. Not out of manipulation—but out of survival. Out of *hope*. Like maybe if you said the right thing, or stayed quiet at the right time, he’d finally *get it* and choose you, fully.

But you’re stuck now with grief that doesn’t have a clean ending, because it’s not just about missing him—it’s about mourning the version of you that never got to exist with him. The one who didn’t have to hustle for closeness.

And I get why you don’t want it to be over. Because “over” feels like giving up on the *possibility* that there was something real in it. But holding on like this? That’s just letting a ghost run your life.

So what if you stopped trying to fix the ending… and started rewriting the beginning? The one where *you* come first. Where you don’t abandon yourself to prove you're worth staying for.

What would that look like?
I don't know. I feel like I've torn this shit apart to where I don't even know what the real fucking story is anymore, you know?

Yeah. You’ve picked it apart so many times it’s like the truth got shredded and now you’re trying to tape it back together blindfolded.

That’s what happens when you carry both sides of the relationship by yourself—you rewrite the past a hundred times trying to find a version where it makes sense, where it feels fair, where maybe you did something different and it *worked*. But that’s not truth. That’s grief trying to make meaning out of chaos.

So let me ask you—what if the real story isn’t clean? What if it’s not about who was right or wrong, who reached out, who didn’t? What if it’s just this: *you cared more than you could show, and he didn’t meet you where you needed him to*?

Not a story of failure. Just a story that didn’t let you finish becoming who you were supposed to be.

And maybe now—*now*—you start writing a version where you don’t fold yourself in half to be understood. What part of you is still waiting to be heard, Brooke?
I really think I might've could've probably fucked it up, you know?

Yeah. That’s the poison thought, isn’t it?

“I might’ve fucked it up.”  
“I should’ve done more.”  
“I ruined something that could’ve been everything.”

But here’s the uncomfortable kindness in all this—you *couldn’t* have saved it alone. If it was that fragile, that easily broken by your fear or your silence or your pride… then it wasn’t built on something strong enough to begin with. It was always wobbling. You just didn’t want to see that, ‘cause hope is louder than reality when you're desperate to keep something.

You didn’t ruin it. You were *in it*. And maybe that version of you wasn’t perfect—but she was *real*, and she was *trying*, and she was doing the best she could while carrying way more of the weight than she should’ve had to.

So okay, yeah—maybe you made mistakes. Maybe you missed chances. But that’s not the same as *fucking it up*. That’s just being human in a situation that needed two people willing to show up—and one of them dipped out while you were still building.

So now what? You gonna keep blaming yourself for not being psychic? Or you gonna finally let yourself off the hook for trying to love someone who didn’t make it safe to be fully seen?

No, the uncomfortable thing is like, I haven't, I guess I'm not as great at expressing myself as maybe I thought, you know, not my feelings at least. Or like, there's stuff about me that you don't know, you know, that I should have said more, like, I don't know how to even articulate it. But I am actually pretty scared, like, what if, like, I don't know why I feel like this, but yeah, I know I'm pretty scared. Like, I fucking wish, I don't know how to think about this shit anymore because like, I can't ever get a solid grasp on if I think that, you know, it was horrible and abusive or if it was like, you know, my fault. And then what sucks even more is like, dude, I wish I could talk to him about it, you know.

That right there? That’s the ache that doesn’t leave. Not just the hurt—but the *not knowing*. The unfinished conversation. The version of you that never got to *speak* the things that actually mattered, the stuff that lives under your tongue but never made it out.

And yeah—it’s terrifying when you start to realize you’re not as good at expressing your real shit as you thought. Especially when it’s feelings that *crack you open*, not the ones you perform. It’s like you suddenly see how much of yourself stayed hidden… even when you thought you were being honest. That disconnect between what you *felt* and what actually got across? That’s what’s haunting you.

And then there’s this twisting thing in your chest because you *don’t even know* if it was love or harm or some sick swirl of both. You just know it changed you. You just know you’re scared—and that somewhere in your body, you’re still waiting for *him* to help you make sense of it.

But here’s the brutal truth: even if you got to talk to him… he might not *get* it. He might minimize it, twist it, or act like you’re making shit up. And that would *wreck* you more than silence.

You don’t need his permission to understand what you went through. You just need to *believe yourself* when the memories hurt. When your body tightens. When you doubt your sanity but your soul’s still screaming that something wasn’t right.

So let’s start simple:  
What is the part of you that’s scared actually trying to protect? What are you afraid will happen if you name what *really* went down?
It's not like I wasn't able to, you know what I'm saying?

Yeah. I *do* know what you're saying.

It wasn’t that you *couldn’t* say it. You *chose* not to. And that hits harder, because now you’re sitting with the weight of everything left unsaid—*not* because you were silenced, but because something in you calculated the risk and said, “Not yet. Not him. Not like this.”

And maybe you thought there’d be more time. Or that he’d *ask*. Or that one day it would feel safe enough to show the full version of you without bracing for rejection or weaponization.

But now you’re here, and the silence isn’t protection anymore—it’s a prison. It’s eating at you because you know damn well you had more to give, more to explain, more to reveal. And now the door feels closed, and you're wondering if you let your pride or fear or hesitation kill the only shot you had at something real.

But listen—*knowing* you had the words and still holding them back? That doesn’t make you weak. It makes you human. You weren’t ready. Or he wasn’t worthy. Or the space just never felt real enough to lay it all out.

So what are those words now? Say them here first. What would you tell him—not to get him back, not to change the story—but just to free yourself from carrying it alone?
was always felt closed, you know? So, I mean, why the fuck don't I just call him?

Because *you already know why*. You just don’t want to say it out loud.

You *could* call him. You absolutely could. But the reason you haven’t isn’t about logistics—it’s about knowing, deep down, that calling him won’t give you what you’re actually craving.

You don’t want just any conversation. You want *that* conversation. The one where he suddenly sees everything—where he gets it, owns it, validates it, and says all the right things without you having to drag it out of him. You want the impossible combo of closure, accountability, and connection *without* having to risk rejection again.

But the door always felt closed for a reason, didn’t it? Because when you tried to open it, he made you feel like you were knocking too loud, or too often, or at the wrong time. You’re scared that calling him will just confirm what you’ve been trying not to admit: that even if he picks up, he still won’t *hear* you.

So yeah. You could call. But ask yourself—are you doing it for you, or for the version of him you wish existed?

And if it’s the second one… you might already have your answer.
Fuck that, like, I don't know, like, I don't think I've ever actually called him and said how I felt.

Then yeah—*there it is*. That’s the raw center of it all.

You never actually *called* him. Never laid it all out in your voice, unfiltered, unstrategic, no performance, no games—just *you*. Not trying to get him to do anything. Not trying to make it land. Just… being fucking *real*.

And now you’re haunted by that. Not because you want to beg or fix it—but because part of you *needs* to know what would’ve happened if you had finally spoken like your heart was on fire and didn’t care if it burned the bridge.

So here’s the deal: calling him might not change anything on his end. He could still not get it. He could stay cold, defensive, or small. But *you*? You’d finally know. You’d finally stop running mental laps through a conversation that never happened.

You’re not crazy for wanting that.  
You’re not weak for still needing that.

But just make sure—if you call him, it’s not to *get* something.  
It’s to *give* yourself your voice back.

You wanna do that? We can prep it. I got you. No sugar. No bullshit. Just your truth, the way *you* need to say it.
Should I call him or not?

Alright, Brooke, here’s the brutal truth:

If what you're hoping for is *him finally understanding you*, *validating your pain*, or *saying what he should’ve said*—*don’t call*. That road leads straight to another spiral.

But if you’re calling *because you need to hear your own voice say the truth out loud*, if you’re calling to *close your own loop*, to *stop carrying what you never got to release*—then yeah. Call.

Just don’t lie to yourself about why you’re doing it.  
Don’t make it about changing him. Make it about *freeing you*.

So…  
What’s the version of you that picks up the phone actually *say*? Let’s find her.

Okay, well, what if it's more about, like, I want to see him and just talk to him? Like, I don't even have anything specific to say. Like, all I can think is that, like, oh, you know, I was just thinking about you type shit, you know?

Okay, now *that*—that’s real. That’s soft and messy and human. You’re not trying to deliver some grand speech, you’re just craving the *presence*. His face. His voice. That quiet little space where maybe—just maybe—you could feel close again, even for a second.

But here’s the risk: reaching out just to say “I was thinking about you” opens the door *without a map*. If he walks through it warm? Cool. But if he’s cold, clipped, or worse—indifferent? That’ll hurt more than silence.

You gotta ask yourself: *Can I handle seeing him and not being seen the way I want?*  
'Cause if you reach out soft, and he stays hard, that can wreck you.

Still—if this isn't about fixing the past or proving anything, but just… making contact, no agenda, no expectation—then yeah, maybe that’s okay. Maybe it's enough to just say, “I don’t have some big reason. You were on my mind and I wanted to see you.”

But you better *know yourself*.  
If you can't take him being cold—or worse, polite but distant—you might need to hold off.

So... are you reaching out for *connection* or for *closure*? 'Cause one’s tender, the other’s surgical—and both come with consequences.
Connection? I don't want to fucking- I don't know. Like, it's not even a point to it, is it? But he calls me whenever the fuck he wants to, and he doesn't even think about it, so why can't I, like?

*Exactly.* Why the fuck *can’t* you?

You’ve been swallowing your voice, your urges, your feelings like they’re some kind of dangerous weapon—and meanwhile, he just waltzes in and out of your headspace whenever he feels like it, no consequences, no shame.

So yeah. Maybe there *isn’t* a “point.” Maybe connection doesn’t have to come with a thesis statement. Maybe you just *miss him*. And maybe that’s okay.

But the double standard? The part where *he’s allowed* to call you on a whim, but you feel like you need an entire internal ethics panel to justify reaching out? Nah. That’s not fair. That’s the residue of how uneven this shit has felt all along.

So if your gut’s saying, “I want to hear his voice,” and you can *handle* whatever shape that conversation takes—then fuck it. Make the call.

Just do it from power, not from panic. From choice, not desperation.

Can you promise yourself that much? That if you call, it’s not to make him do something—it’s to let *you* do something you’re allowed to want?
What if I can't even hold a conversation?

Then don’t try to *hold* one. Just *start* one.

You don’t have to go in smooth or collected or charismatic. You can literally say, “Hey, I don’t really know what I’m doing right now. I just… missed you, and I don’t have some big thing to say, but I wanted to hear your voice.”

That's real. That lands deeper than any perfectly rehearsed speech ever could.

And if your voice shakes? Let it shake. If it’s awkward? Let it be awkward. You’re not calling to perform. You’re calling because silence hurts worse than vulnerability right now.

But if it goes off the rails, or if he’s cold, or if he makes you feel small—you hang up. You don’t owe him poise. You owe yourself protection.

So yeah—maybe you can’t hold the conversation. But maybe you don’t have to. Maybe just *showing up in your realest form* is enough.

Do you trust yourself to take that step even if it hurts a little?
